text: well Tony Benn once said that the way
that the government treats refugees is
very instructive because it's the way
they would treat the rest of us if they
had after chance I think it's a it seems
to me to be a week where where the
debate in this country has been somewhat
Corson's in the way that we've seen
within the United States of America the
try to get rid of John Bercow because he
spoke out the prime minister accusing
Jeremy Corbyn of using alternative facts
and this seems to be part and part of
this this harshness I mean we have a
duty to take in refugees from around the
world and I think that particularly
these young people because they're kind
of stuck between a rock and a hard place
we lent on the French government to
clear the Calais jungle these people are
stuck there they're what no way to go
they can't go back where they came from
they can't assimilate into France we've
said our government has said that and
we've undertaken thankfully to the the
Dubs amendment and Alf Dobbs was himself
a child refugee that we would take them
in and I think it says something about a
coarseness of the debate that's going on
about the moment in in our country you
know we have we have some real thinking
to do in the coming years not just about
article 50 or or whether we want to
stand a single market or to join the
economic area we have to ask ourselves
what kind of people are we are we going
to turn away
we're going to turn away from our
responsibilities to the world or are we
going to step up and do what we said we
would do and take all 3000 of these
refugees right
